an3.126:3.3: This suggests that they were part of the same spiritual community during the six years before the Buddha’s awakening. The commentary says that he was in fact a student of Āḷāra Kālāma.
an3.126:5.4: These three are treated in detail at [mn13](). At [an10.29:21.4]() the Buddha says he is sometime falsely accused of not teaching the full understanding of these three things. That sutta also refers indirectly to the teachings of Āḷāra Kālāma and Uddaka son of Rāma.
an3.126:6.2: If this is an accurate depiction of Āḷāra Kālāma’s teachings, it suggests that he was a teacher of “oneness” not “diversity”. Presumably, in line with Upaniṣadic philosophy, he saw the differences between them as partial manifestations of the immanent cosmic self (see eg. Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.14).
